abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Haploinsufficiency of the transcription factor PAX6 is the main cause of congenital aniridia, a genetic disorder characterized by iris and foveal hypoplasia. 11p13 microdeletions altering <jats:italic>PAX6</jats:italic> or its downstream regulatory region (DRR) are present in about 25% of patients; however, only a few complex rearrangements have been described to date. Here, we performed nanopore-based whole-genome sequencing to assess the presence of cryptic structural variants (SVs) on the only two unsolved “<jats:italic>PAX6</jats:italic>-negative” cases from a cohort of 110 patients with congenital aniridia after unsuccessfully short-read sequencing approaches.
</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Long-read sequencing (LRS) unveiled balanced chromosomal rearrangements affecting the <jats:italic>PAX6 locus</jats:italic> at 11p13 in these two patients and allowed nucleotide-level breakpoint analysis. First, we identified a cryptic 4.9 Mb de novo inversion disrupting intron 7 of <jats:italic>PAX6,</jats:italic> further verified by targeted polymerase chain reaction amplification and sequencing and FISH-based cytogenetic analysis<jats:italic>.</jats:italic> Furthermore, LRS was decisive in correctly mapping a  t(6;11) balanced translocation  cytogenetically detected in a second proband with congenital aniridia and considered non-causal 15 years ago. LRS resolved that the breakpoint on chromosome 11 was indeed located at 11p13, disrupting the DNase I hypersensitive site 2 enhancer within the DRR of <jats:italic>PAX6,</jats:italic> 161 Kb from the causal gene. Patient-derived RNA expression analysis demonstrated <jats:italic>PAX6</jats:italic> haploinsufficiency, thus supporting that the 11p13 breakpoint led to a positional effect by cleaving crucial enhancers for <jats:italic>PAX6</jats:italic> transactivation. LRS analysis was also critical for mapping the exact breakpoint on chromosome 6 to the highly repetitive centromeric region at 6p11.1.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>In both cases, the LRS-based identified SVs have been deemed the hidden pathogenic cause of congenital aniridia. Our study underscores the limitations of traditional short-read sequencing in uncovering pathogenic SVs affecting low-complexity regions of the genome and the value of LRS in providing insight into hidden sources of variation in rare genetic diseases.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

group.label: Ethics approval and consent to participate
group.name: EthicsHeading

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study was approved by the Ethics Research Committee of the University Hospital Fundación Jimenez Díaz (PICO15_18_FJD and PIC059-21) and complied with the guidelines of the Declaration of Helsinki and further reviews. All participants or their legal guardians gave written informed consent to participate and publish genetic and clinical data.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no competing interests.
